segments.text: very much surprised at how peaceful things seemed to be.
It had no sense of impending doom or anything.
Can you carry us from that point till you got back to your hotel?
One of the things that I was thinking was I wish that our whole family was there so that they could see what's going on.
There's no way, I knew there was no way I could explain how peaceful and how cooperative these people were because many times when we were over here,
Very seldom do we see people helping each other out, people united in a common cause, a common idea.
And even when you would try to get on a Chinese bus, it was survival of the fittest.
And they would run over you to get onto the bus.
But here, you had more people in a potentially dangerous situation, but they were very calm.
They were very helpful to each other.
It just, it was something that we had never experienced.
You're comparing the crowd in June of 1989 as peaceful and calm compared to the daily activity, crowds, and movement in Beijing back in your 85, 86 school year.
Yes, yes.
I said there were more people, and I said there were just, you could see that these people, although I could not understand what they were saying, that they were pleading with these troops
not to go into Tiananmen Square.
You felt that's what they were doing?
Oh, yeah.
There was no doubt in my mind.

They were trying to tell these troops that these were people down in Tiananmen Square, students and otherwise, and that they were not ruffians or hooligans that were causing destruction or anything like that, and trying to explain the general situation and what was going on.
It was a very...
friendly type of thing.

The soldiers were doing more listening than talking, and they had a rather solemn look on their face for the most part, but it was not what it could have been and what I could have imagined as a confrontational type of situation, even though there were, I would guess here at this intersection by this time, there were maybe 5,000 to 10,000 people, because they literally covered
This whole interchange there was thick with people.
But I said it was a very peaceful atmosphere.
And people did not seem to be afraid.
I mean, when somebody's afraid, you can see it in their eyes.
You can see it in the way they were acting.
And these people were not acting that way.
It was a very friendly type of thing.
And the Chinese people, they love their children.
They're not going to put their children
what they would feel is a potentially dangerous situation.
Yet there were children all over.
They were playing on the grass nearby, and walking around, and children talking with troops too.
So it was a very peaceful setting.
So you were still walking, still heading for the taxi?
So about 9.30, I figured, well, you know, I better go ahead and get back again.
Nothing out of the ordinary seemed to be happening.
So I walked on to the Friendship store.
It was closed by this time, so there weren't any taxis there, so I had to go down to one of the foreign hotels that's a little bit further on.
And there were a couple of taxis there, but they weren't too enthused about taking someone somewhere, so I had to bargain
with this guy.
He wanted 50 or 60 yuan to take me what is usually a 15 yuan drive.
He said, oh yeah, but there's a lot of demonstrators out and stuff.
So we bargained down to 25 yuan to take me over to my hotel.
What was the name of your hotel again?
I was at the Kunlun Hotel, which is in the northeast side of the city.
So I got into the cab.
And he started down one of the main streets of parallels, that ring road, to get over to where my hotel was.
And we came on.
There weren't a whole lot of people out in the street.
We came on one intersection where the students or the people had pulled buses across to block this main street.
There were about a half a dozen buses
in kind of a half-moon shape so that they'd block the street that we were on on the other side of the intersection and the two that were coming in.
Figured that if convoys tried to come in that way, they wouldn't be able to get around that.
But fortunately, there was enough space that he could get the car between two of the buses.
And you have the main street, and then they have these separate bicycle lanes on the side.
And a lot of times there's a divider with some grass that's in between the main street and the bicycle lane.
He had to go over the bicycle lane to go down that.
But it was to get back on the street after we got past that.
So I got back to the hotel then until about 10 o'clock in the evening, Beijing time, and called home.
to tell my wife and the kids that everything was okay.
I felt I couldn't tell them that I'd just been down to the square and I'd just run into a bunch of troops.
You felt you couldn't tell them?
I felt I could not.
Number one, because you don't know who may be listening in on the phone.
And I did not want to draw any suspicion on myself.
But you didn't have any difficulty making the phone call out.
I didn't have any difficulty making the phone call out.
And my daughter answered the phone.
And my wife had just taken our youngest son to his t-ball game.
But I told my daughter, I said, hey, you know, everything's fine.
You know, just, you know, come on over.
And I tried to explain without telling her where I had been and what I had done.
I tried to tell her to bring along some extra cash.
So because one of the things that the students needed was money, and particularly with dollars in that, they could get a lot more in terms of food and things like that.
I wanted to have that ability to make some donations, but I needed cash rather than traveler's checks.
So without telling her what I wanted it for, I was trying to explain to bring that over and wanted them to bring some
Texas A&M t-shirts over so that we could get our pictures taken in front of the Goddess of Democracy with our A&M t-shirts.
And as we were talking, and apparently she had been watching television, she said that they had just broken in on the news and said that there was some shooting going on in Beijing.
And I told her, I said, well, if there is, that must be an isolated incident that wasn't really...
and that everything was peaceful.
Now, she's watching TV on Sunday night?
No, this was Saturday morning here.
It was Saturday night in Beijing.
It was Saturday morning back here in the state.
So she, I told her everything was fine, and, you know, to tell her mother that everything was okay and we were coming over.
So I went ahead and went to bed, and then about
An hour later, my wife had gotten back from the T-ball game.
She called me and said, you know, are you sure that everything's okay?
Because they're talking about some real shooting going on.
And I said, well, you know, I can't, I was on the northeast side.
I was about two and a half, three miles away from Tiananmen Square.
I couldn't hear anything in my room.
And I told her, you know, I thought everything was okay, but
I, as it turned out, I was in one of the few hotels in Beijing that has a satellite hookup to CNN.
And so I said, you know what, I'll turn on the TV and see what I can see from here.
And instructed her to go ahead and call me early Sunday morning, Beijing time, which would be Saturday evening, her time, so that we could assess the situation to see what's going on.
early on Sunday morning, she was going to have to drive to Houston, Sunday morning Houston time, drive to Houston to take our kids and put them on the plane.

So, I then stayed up that night watching CNN, watching what was going on, and was as horrified as, you know, everybody back in the States, as to why I was just, and thinking, you know, I was just, I was just down there, and piecing things together, since I've been back,

realized that just about the time that I left that group on the east side of Tiananmen Square, another group of soldiers from this unit that was in Mongolia had come down Chong Lin Avenue from the west side.
And when the people came out to stop them, just as they had done to this convoy that I had been with, those guys didn't stop.
They opened fire.
on the people and ran over people and continued down on to in the Tiananmen Square.
And that apparently was the shooting that my daughter had first heard being reported.
I do know that later that night, early Sunday morning, in that area where I was, that that's where some of the tanks came through.
Now, there's no way of knowing whether the troops that I saw then ended up shooting at the people who were around there or they remained peaceful and did not shoot.
One of the things that I have found out since returning was that those soldiers were told by their commanders that when they were given the order to shoot, they better shoot.
And if they didn't, that the commander would kill them right on the spot.
As a matter of fact, that
And where did you obtain that information?
I obtained information from a lot of different sources, from contacts, from some, there were four students, a newspaper, people from Hong Kong who were in the square that night.
And they were, they came to A&M.

afterwards to discuss their experiences and from other contexts that I know but feel that for their own safety that I shouldn't identify them can I take you back then to when you're in the hotel in the middle of the night watching the television coverage what was probably the most vivid scene that you remember from watching television at that point in time they
they were showing mainly still pictures.
Of course, the government was trying its best to keep the news media from being able to send out information.
And there wasn't any one in particular that stands out.
The thought that kept going through my mind was the fact that I had just been down there and things were so peaceful.
And that
The only thought in my mind was how desperate the hard lines, the government, Deng Xiaoping, Li Peng, and that, were to maintain their power.
Because this was an act of sheer desperation.
I was convinced that it was not a case where the people had turned unruly and had forced the army into a situation where they needed a machine to protect themselves.

It was clear in my mind, and piecing things together since I've come back, very clear that the government had made the cold-blooded, calculated decision to go in there and to clear the square by whatever violent means were necessary.
Okay, so you were watching television, hearing commotion in the hotel?
What did you finally do with the phone call to your wife?
There was not a lot of commotion going to the hotel because there weren't a whole lot of people in the hotel.
Tourism had been cut down drastically because of that.
I couldn't help but think about the people that I'd seen down in the square and wondering if they had left already, that little boy that I'd seen, his mother, and the
The high school girl in the back was a translator.
I couldn't help but wondering if they were still there, if they were part of what was going on, if they had been able to get out of there.
My wife was able to get a hold of me the next morning, and we both agreed that it was not wise to put the kids on the plane.
Even though they wanted to come, we felt that it would be much
safer and easier for me to get out of there if I just had to worry about myself.
So you made this decision over the phone early Sunday morning.
Yeah, and I said this was this was about five or six hours before she would have gotten in the car and taken down to the Houston airport and I told her that my plans were that I was going to
that there was nothing open on Sunday.
There was no way that I could make any arrangements to get out early on Sunday.
As it turned out, I had, whatever possible, do not want to fly the Chinese airline, fly other airlines.
So I had all foreign travel, except my daughter
was going to, when we left, we were going to stop in Hong Kong, and she was going to stay an extra week with one of her friends that she had gone to school with when they were in Beijing.
So we had already booked a flight for the following Sunday to go from Beijing to Hong Kong.
We had to fly the Chinese airline for that leg, which turned out to be good in that I had a ticket then on the Chinese airline from Beijing to Hong Kong, and they had an office

There was the Great Royal Hotel a block away from where I was staying, whereas all the other foreign airlines, the only place that they had their offices were down in the hotels near Tiananmen Square.
So I did not want to go down to that part of the city.
So I told them that on Monday morning, they would open at 9 o'clock, and then I would be over there, you know, when they opened, be one of the first people there, and see if I could get out early.
You know, if I couldn't, that...
I felt that I was safe enough or that I knew of where I could, you know, places to hide, stuff like that, that I would just wait, you know, get out on the following Sunday.

But to have instructed her to call me back around noon on Monday, Beijing time, because that way hopefully I would have information to be able to tell her what arrangements, if any, I'd been able to make.
So, the Sunday I continued to watch
CNN, and they were beginning to get more coverage and pictures of what was going on.
And I said, I knew that what we're dealing here with was a desperate government that was acting in a very desperate way to maintain its power.
So before that, I felt that I could probably judge and predict what was going to happen sufficiently ahead of time to be able to get out of any danger.
But here, you were acting
You were dealing with people who were completely irrational, illogical.
And the troops were, even though I, by watching CNN, knew where the main concentrations of what was going on, where they were, they still had patrols that were going around the city.
And those patrols, if they saw a group of people, they might decide to just open up and start shooting at them.
So I knew it was not safe to
Too much traveling around the city.

As a matter of fact, my plans originally, I was supposed to, one Sunday afternoon, I was supposed to change hotels and go over to the west side of town and stay in the place where we had lived before.
And that's where our kids were going to stay with me.
That was the Friendship Hotel?
The Friendship Hotel.
But realized that that's also where Beijing University and People's University and a lot of universities are.
And that the military, once they got things under control in Tiananmen Square, that they were going to head for the university.
So I made arrangements to go ahead and continue on in the hotel, in the Canoon Hotel, where I was.
I ventured out a couple of times, just a little bit, right around the hotel there.
There was very little traffic.
on what's normally going on on Sunday.
But you begin to see some people kind of clustered together in small groups, I think, passing on information about what was going on down in Tiananmen Square.
Again, the government controls all the news media, and of course they weren't admitting what was going on.
The only way people knew was by word of mouth and people spreading the word, not getting it in conventional ways by seeing what's going on in television news.
or what have you.
And I also realized that from our previous day that contacting our embassy and asking for their help to get out of there was a waste of my time because those people, they don't know what's going on.
And my suspicions were confirmed both by my own personal experience.
When I did get out, I met some people who as late as Monday afternoon
our embassy was advising American tourists to continue to come to Beijing if there was no problem.
Okay, so the embassy is not something you tried to contact.
No.
You're still then in contact in trying to get this flight out to Hong Kong.
I went to sleep that night.
I watched TV on and off.
And then Monday morning, got up, ate a good breakfast, and went over to the Great Wall Sheraton Hotel.
and was one of the first there to get in line.
I think that because of my having been there before, I was one of the few foreigners that realized the seriousness of the situation.
It wasn't until late Tuesday or Wednesday that the other Americans and tourists in that realized how dangerous the situation was and tried to get out.
So there was a group of 15 or 20 of us there who

most of them were people who were working for corporations and that who had been in Beijing for a number of months and lived there and they realized how serious the things were and were trying to get out.
I couldn't get a flight out on Monday.
The earliest one that I could get changed to was a flight that left early Tuesday morning.
There were actually two flights.
One went directly from Beijing to Hong Kong and the other one from Beijing to Tianjin which is
a major port city in China.
It's on the coast about 120 miles from Beijing.
But it went from Beijing to Tianjin to Hong Kong.
So I had the lady go ahead and change my ticket and put me on that flight.
Now, I'm somewhat concerned because China does not have the tourist and travel facilities we have here.
We just call them a travel agent.
Through the computers, they can
book flights and reservations anywhere you want.
The Chinese still did not have round-trip tickets.
They're just now beginning to get some of their major ticket offices hooked together by a computer.
So even though this lady had on her computer, she had put it in, I wasn't sure, I wasn't comfortable that it had been confirmed out of the airport.
Your skepticism grew a little bit out of your previous experiences with Reagan.
Okay, China.
So I went back to the hotel, and my wife was able to get through until about 12, 30, quarter to 1.
It was still easier for people from outside to call in than it was for us to call out.
Did you try to call out?
I had tried to call out once earlier, but I couldn't get a line.
I couldn't get an outside line.
So she got in, and I told her what my plans were and that,
I was concerned about being able to get out to the airport because, as I said, it's outside of town.
And there were very few buses that were running.
There really weren't any buses that you could take directly out to the airport anyway.
But there were also very few taxis.
Usually at the hotels, there was one of 20 or 30 taxis.
Sunday and Monday, I'd only seen two or three that had come by and were dropping people off.
There weren't a lot of taxis out there.
I didn't want to...

alarm her too much, but I told her, you know, what I was going to do is I was just going to go ahead after I finished talking with her, and I was going to go out to the airport, you know, I'd sleep out there tonight, so that way I'd be out there, so in case the military decided they were going to close off the city or something, you know, that I'd at least be outside the city.
And I assured her that, you know, I knew my way around, and she felt comfortable with that because we lived there.
She knew by watching television back here what was going on
you know, where the troops were, where the action was, and, you know, that I had some friends there, and that, you know, I had a good chance of being able to take care of myself.
And both of us, I think, as we look back, felt unusually comfortable.
Wasn't really scared or too worried at that point in time.
We both feel that...
that the Lord was with us and was...
I could have very easily been down in Tiananmen Square.
I could have run into troops that were shooting at me and felt comfortable in that sense, that it felt like the Lord was taking care of me as I was going through all this.
So after I finished talking with her, I went downstairs and ate a big meal at the hotel because I didn't know when I'd get my next one.
They also had a small grocery store there in the hotel.
I went in there and bought a couple of canned hams, some bottled water, some Vienna sausage type things, and some crackers, and some bread type stuff.
And then went up to my room and rearranged my stuff.
I had a light bag that I put
that I could carry very easily.
I put some of the food in there and some of the things that I felt were more necessities in my bigger, hard-sided bag.
I put things that I could do without if I had to ditch that.
And I went to the desk and changed some of my money into
dollars, got some dollars.
You have to convert into foreign exchange.
I got some of that.
I had some Chinese local currency, and I also had some dollars.
And I spread those around on my body and in my different bags so that if I was separated from one of them, I wouldn't have all my eggs in one basket, so to speak.
And I brought along a Swiss Army knife because that's helpful in the
as we found out before, and fortunately had that with me, so I put that in my pocket.

And then went down and waited for a cab, and fortunately, about half an hour after I got out there, somebody was coming to, because tourists, American tourists, were still arriving Monday afternoon, and I talked back and had to bargain with this guy again, but got him to take me out to the airport,
I was somewhat concerned because normally there's just a taxi driver.
But in this cab, there was a taxi driver.
There was a friend of his also sitting in the front seat.
And I was concerned that these guys might try to rob me or they might take me out somewhere and leave me off there.
But it was the only cab that had come around.
So I figured I'd go ahead and take a chance.
And so I got in the back seat.
I let him put the heavy bag in the trunk, but I kept the other kind of carry-on bag type thing with me.
And I had my pocket knife.
That would have done me, I don't know, but easily accessible to me.
And we got into the cab and we started going out there.
And the driver knew a little bit of English and started a little bit of a conversation.
And he had...
a copy of a fax that they had received earlier in the day from Hong Kong.
What the students and the people in Beijing were doing was they were getting most of their information from outside China, from Hong Kong.
And what they would do was in Hong Kong, they would watch what was going on from the news and from their contacts, the people that they knew, and then they would write it out in Chinese characters.
Then they would fax it to Beijing, and then
people are sympathetic to the demonstrations.
They would take them, and they would run off copies, which is very difficult to get access to a copy machine in China.
It's not like here, where you just run down to Kiko's or someplace, four cents a copy place.
And they would make copies, and then they would, as I mentioned, the students were distributing these, putting them on light poles and stuff like that.
But this guy had a stack of them, and he gave me one of them, which I've had translated since I came back.
And it was dealing with the massacre that's going on
Saturday night, Sunday morning.
It was square, what was going on, Tiananmen Square.
And as we were going, I knew, again, because I'd been there, I knew the general streets and the general directions.
So I was watching very carefully as to where these guys were taking me, so that I could tell if they were taking me or not.
But they were going the route that you would go to get out there.
And on two occasions, we passed a major intersection
where there were several trucks of troops over on the side.
And they were armed, but they weren't out there blocking off the street or that.
They were just kind of camped over to the side.
Well, the second group that we came up to was at the intersection of the road that goes out to the airport.

lido the holiday inn is located right there on that intersection there were about four trucks they were there the troops they were out they were they were eating and mulling around and the driver as we started to go on this intersection he started rolling down his window and grabbed one of these faxes to give these soldiers and i thought you know this guy is going to get us killed right here and
I was glad that his friend was in the front seat with him because his friend kind of, you know, nudged him on the arm and, you know, shook his head, you know, don't do this.
And so he turned all over on the seat next to us so that even somebody looking in couldn't see him and rolled the window back up and we drove on.
And it was great news with that.
We got out to the airport.
It was about 4 o'clock in the afternoon.
And one time I see the United Airlines flight that my kids were supposed to come in.
It was supposed to get into Beijing Monday night.
And what it does is it's coming and going.
